property.name: text
property.value: Authors: Edward A. Lee and Haiyang Zheng

property.name: text
property.value: Look inside the ModalModel to see how this is implemented.

property.name: text
property.value:
This is a stochastic hybrid system modeling hysteresis where the time it takes to react to a threshold crossing is random. Specifically, when the sinewave crosses the lowThreshold going down, then after a random delay, the output goes low. When the sinewave crosses the highThreshold going up, then after another random delay, the output goes high.
Some hybrid systems formalisms define guards so that when a guard is true, a transition is enabled. In such a formalism, the time between when a guard becomes true and the transition is taken is nondeterministic. This model illustrates how to get the same effect using the Ptolemy II semantics, where as soon as a guard becomes true, the transition is always taken.

property.name: text
property.value: This test is not that much use because we use random() in an expression and we can't set a seed.

property.name: text
property.value: Look inside either wait state to see the state refinements.

property.name: text
property.value:
State machine with one state for each output value plus a state that models the time it takes to make a transition. In this model, the time it takes to make the transition is random. It is uniformly distributed between zero and the value of the maximumDelay parameter.
Note that all four states, high, low, wait1, and wait2, have the same refinement, called "constant" which outputs a constant. In addition, the two wait states have a second refinement called "wait" that triggers an event after a specified time.

property.name: text
property.value: Output a constant value given by the parameter outputValue.

property.name: text
property.value: Output the elapsed time since entry. Note that this requires resetting the integrator on entry.

property.name: text
property.value: Make the time accessible on an output so that we can check whether it is <= 0.0. In those cases, the LevelCrossingDetector will not trigger, and we'll get stuck.
